title: Vehicle-to-Vehicle and Vehicle-to Infrastructure Linkages
segmentation: OK.
Thank you Mr. Moderator and thanks everybody.
Sorry for being a little bit late.
I was just rushing from the airport and running last part here.
But anyway, here I am.
It's the last presentation for today.
I'm going to try to be quick and speak as much as I can in pictures.
Last week when I was preparing my presentation for tomorrow session on the corporate vehicle infrastructure systems, I got a question.
Would you like to present another topic as well?
Which by the chance was vehicle to vehicle and vehicle to infrastructure linkages and that is more or less exactly what corporate vehicles infrastructure systems is all about.
That is one of the projects in this area, so I gladly accept this.

Invitation and I decided to put myself in a little bit higher level so if I mentioned CVS too many times today, please stop listening to me or throw Pandora Blocker or something on me because this presentation should be giving you a little bit of a framework little flavor.
What vehicle to vehicle and vehicle to infrastructure communication is all about all the possibilities.
Not only one project, but to give you an overview what is happening in Europe and what will be in depth be presented tomorrow.
During present during Session 7.6, cooperative approaches to mobility.
OK.
So shortly though, the outline I'm going to be talking about what can be proved, I think you have heard most of it from the present other presenters today, so I will not be very long with that one.
I will give you an introduction to cooperative systems, gives few examples of cooperative systems.

Talk about ongoing activities in Europe especially, and then after that I'm going to be spending a few minutes on deployment enablers and all of this just to give you a flavor or what is going to be discussed tomorrow.
We
Other colleagues.
OK, where should I point there?
Right, So what can be improved?

We have been working on traffic management systems for quite some time now, and looking at the situation in London, for example 40 years ago and few years ago, we can see that there is some possibility for improvements.
It can cope like that.
Additionally, Traffic Safety is not where we want it to be.
In Sweden there is Vision 0.
For example.
The government has stated that they would like to have zero fatalities on Swedish roads by 2010.
If I'm not wrong, we're not reaching that right now.
Additionally, in Europe we have also seen similar activities and similar goals, but it's it's a long way for us to even half the number of fatalities on.
Rose this bar.

So one thing that many, many partners in Europe, many stakeholders in Europe today believe is this is the solution is the Golden egg and many vehicle manufacturers Rd operators, public authorities, etc etc etc.
Everybody believes that Corporation or cooperative systems or vehicle to vehicle vehicle to infrastructure communications are different names that will bring us the beach benefits.
In the future.
And we see here example that we have two vehicles communicating directly with each other to send some kind of important messages.
Hey, I'm breaking or have just had an accident.
Slow down.
Don't don't hit me or other safety relevant information.
Of course we have infrastructure.
Infrastructure today cannot communicate with vehicles in that extent that we would like to have in the future.
For example, when you're approaching traffic signal, you do not know.
In your vehicle, when the traffic signal will switch to yellow and then to red or the other way around.
On the sensor side, we already have a number of systems implemented today.
As we have heard from our PTI presentation.
But the entire concept of every vehicle sending information and receiving information for security and efficiency.
It's quite new, because now technology allows us to have this vision that we can equip every vehicle and every roadside element.
For example, traffic signal with the communication unit.
OK, I apologize for this.
It's late, but not that late.
So what are the elements of this corporate division?
This is 1 vision that we're in CVS project one time.
The vehicle, of course, is one of the key.
If not the main one, the.
Element in the system.
Of course, we have our own side unit.
We have central systems and we also see handhelds.
It sounds like communication mobile telephones or Tom Toms etc etc.
As one of the parts or one of the elements of this future corporate.
New systems.
Now looking at applications, what can we achieve?

Once we have this vision of every car and every roadside infrastructure to being able to talk with each other, what can you achieve that in this case we see few examples for interurban interurban applications.
It's possible to cluster these corporate applications.
Different areas.
This is 1 possibility.
So as mentioned we have one one car detecting is danger and sending that information directly to occur in behind.
There is also possibility too that this yellow car will forward the message to the next coming car so that the entire convoy gets to know that there is danger on the road.
Let's slow down or even stop.
We also have a traffic information messages.
As you can see here.
You can shorten your time once you know where all the cars are, you can know that they are accused there and there.
But you can also predict much better than you can today.
Where are where is your car going for example, and what the most optimal route for you will be in one hour from now.
Additionally, we also have a, for example map download or another infotainment service.
This.
I think I need documents.
OK looking to urban area.
And we have a number of applications there as well.
For example re routing if there has been a traffic accident or similar as one example.
Yeah, but of course all of these applications that we've been talking about this for it.

Of course, if you would like to have a car in front of you, sending information to you that he has detected danger and that you can rely on that information, you have to have quite high penetration or vehicles that are equipped vehicles and infrastructure that are equipped with these communication devices.
Now that is one of the problems with cooperative systems today that we will not go from zero penetration to 100 one 100% penetration overnight.
So what can we do in between there we will have?
Equipped a number of vehicles in the beginning roadside units but not many people will be benefiting from that.
For example, if my car can broadcast message here I am, I can detect the danger.
That's not very useful if none of the other cars around me doesn't have the communication possibilities.
So looking how to overcome that barrier and how to convince you as a consumer or a driver to buy the communication device anyway.
This for example flexible Lane usage could be one of the examples.
If you're in a city bus lanes today are very expensive to put on the roads so say and they are not very well used.
However, if you will have vehicles that are communicating and sending out their position and are aware about the where the other.
Buses are or other vehicles are.
You can, for example, for early adopters of cooperative systems.
Give right to use the bus lanes as one of the incentives.
Potential incentives.
Yeah.

In one of the projects, no name there has been in the simulation done on how would this affect how this specific application affect, for example, throughput of buses on bus lanes, and it has been shown that with.
With the number of cars that can use the bus lanes, the benefits compared to the drawbacks are very, very promising.

For example, with 175 additional vehicles per hour in Italy on on the road, including public deley is public transport is delayed only by 3%, which is not very much when you consider that with the same amount of vehicles per hour on the bustling.
Average travel time for private vehicles decreases with 53%.

In this specific case, so if somebody was trying to sell me that system today and say, OK, you will be, you will be able to broadcast message about yourself, but you will have only a limited number of applications where you can use it and this could be one of them that you start with.
This might be interesting.

Additionally, there are also promises for public transport as mentioned over there, but also to other types of transport for commercial vehicles and cooperative freight and fleet management is one of those.
You could have, for example, parking booking when you know that you're arriving to certain sports at that time.

You could automatically rearrange time in case the system knows that you're 5 minutes delayed or 5 minutes early, and we can negotiate automatically so that the driver does not have to be bored about all of this information.
Another type of application is access to certain buildings, or.
Areas.
Looking at the communication possibilities, there is a vast number of communication channels that can be used today.
3G, ordinary Wi-Fi, Wimax etc etc etc.

One of the key communication channels for the future of car to car encarta infrastructure communication will be something called a .211 P. This is a communication on 5.9 giga Hertz broadband and this is the communication communication channel where all safety time critical information will be sent.
So this is the key one and this is the one communication channel that is really uniting all of the.
Initiatives in this field in Europe.

So coming back to the promised, the short presentation or what is what is going on in Europe you can see there are three FT 6 projects ongoing right now and they have just finalized their second year where CIS coordinated by me and my colleagues is the biggest of them.
We are developing an open open platform for future communication between.
Cold calling card infrastructure.

We have another very important project called Saves Put which is dealing with safety time, critical applications looking into intersection, detection of drivers that are violating red light or one of these applications that I showed earlier with cars talking directly to each other to inform each other about the danger.
And the third very important project in this area is Coopers and this is a Rd operators view on how the.
How do these future cooperation could be done?
I would say Alexander, please correct me if this is wrong, but Chris is little bit more using a little bit more mature technology and also is more.
More market close if you can call it like that compared to CVS and save spot.
Except these three major projects, there is a number of other activities, both national and EU level, that are dealing with cooperative systems.
All of this entire floor of these projects and activities just shows you how much money is spent and that people and stakeholders are really serious about getting these systems on the market.

One very important organization in Europe is car to car communication consortium dealing for currently mostly with the vehicle to vehicle and little bit vehicle to infrastructure communications, especially for safety critical applications.
They are very very close link with one of the projects that we have seen previously.
Safe sport.
Other EC supported projects.
As you can see our sister; And, safety sisters do doing satellite navigation with Galileo Servicom is safe communication safe communication and the common safety we will come back to later.
Additionally there is number of national activities.
Network unveils invent active in Germany etc etc etc.
I won't read over.
OK, so now when you see all of these activities you might start thinking what the heck are they all doing?
Are they re doing the work to be honest to a part of the small part, yes we are.
But at the same time we are trying to align as much as possible in Europe so that we have in the other one not form for European research.
One of these support actions is comi safety that is trying to bring together the three mentioned projects that are ongoing right now and also additional projects plus standardization bodies.
And of course cart, cart and sourcing.
So through this activity we are trying to agree on one European architecture.
One set of standards standard messages, so that we really achieve interoperability and all the other necessary means for deployment.
So this was a little bit about application and it's not so much about technology, but about that school activities in this area.
What are deployment barriers, biggest deployment barriers and the biggest enablers that need to be there in order for this system to be put on market?
One is open as Inter interoperability we have heard previously.
Interoperability is very important.
If Mercedes vehicle sends a message to roadside units from peak and they do not understand each other, that is not very cooperative.
Safe, Secure, and fault tolerant design.
Of course, the system should not be hacked.
In any way, they should be accepted by the users.
And of course we have to have everything from cost models, benefits and to understand the real, the advantage and the real benefits of these systems.
And that is one thing that we are working on quite hard now.
Business models are still not very clear for most of these systems.
And the same goes for deployment, Rd Maps and those are the activities that we're working quite quite hard on right now.
Now I have mentioned a little bit about all of these ongoing activities tomorrow.
In the next session you will hear from me going much more detail about CDs and this is the second time I'm mentioning, so it's not too much.

We will hear from Alexander about Coopers and we'll also hear from safe spot representatives much more about the current state of much more about objectives, current state of the art, where what we achieved during the first 2 years.
Where do we want to go in the future?
And of course, what are the biggest barriers?
So please let this be first sample or first inspiration to mention two visit 7.6.
Session tomorrow.
